sen.j: 前田 玄以（まえだ げんい）は、戦国時代から安土桃山時代にかけての武将・大名。
sen.e: Geni MAEDA was the busho (military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the age of provincial wars and the Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Geni MAEDA was a busho (military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Sengoku (Warring States) and the Azuchi-Momoyama periods.
Geni MAEDA was a busho (military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Sengoku (Warring States) and the Azuchi-Momoyama periods.

sen.j: 豊臣政権における五奉行の1人であり、丹波亀山藩の初代藩主である。
sen.e: He was one of the Go bugyo of the TOYOTOMI Administration and was the first head of the Tamba Kameyama Han.
He was one of the Go-Bugyo (Five Commissioners) of the TOYOTOMI Administration and was the first head of the Tamba Kameyama Han (or fief).
sen.cmt: Go bugyo'→'Go-Bugyo'Added translation of Japanese terms.
sen.e: He was one of the Gobugyo (Five Major Magistrates) of the TOYOTOMI Administration and was the first head of the Tamba Kameyama Domain (or fief).

sen.j: 天文8年（1539年）、前田基光の子として美濃国（現在の岐阜県）で生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the son of Maeda Motomitsu in Mino no Kuni (Mino Province) in 1539.
He was born in the province of Mino no Kuni (present day Gifu Prefecture) in 1539, the son of Maeda Motomitsu.
sen.cmt: Changed word orderAdded 'in the province of'Added '(present day Gifu Prefecture)' as in original
sen.e: He was born in the province of Mino no Kuni (present day Gifu Prefecture) in 1539, the son of Motomitsu MAEDA.

sen.j: はじめ尾張国小松原寺の僧侶であったが、後に比叡山延暦寺に入った。
sen.e: He was originally the monk of Komatsu-dera Temple in Owari no Kuni but later entered Enryaku-ji Temple of Mt. Hiei.
sen.cmt: 小松原寺→Komatsubara-dera Temple or Komatsubara-ji Temple
sen.e: He was originally a monk at Komatsu-dera Temple in Owari no Kuni but later entered Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei.
He was originally a monk at Komatsubara-dera Temple in Owari no Kuni but later entered Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: しかし織田信長に招聘されて織田氏の家臣となった。
sen.e: However, he was invited by Nobunaga ODA and became the retainer of Oda Family.
However, he was invited by Nobunaga ODA to become the retainer of the ODA Family.
However, he was invited by Nobunaga ODA to become the retainer of the ODA Clan.

sen.j: 後に信長の命令でその嫡男・織田信忠付の家臣となる。
sen.e: He became the retainer for Nobunaga's legitimate son, Nobutada ODA under Nobunaga's command.
Later, on Nobunaga's orders, he became a retainer of Nobunaga's son, Nobutada ODA.
sen.cmt: Changed word order'the retainer for'→'a retainer of''under Nobunaga's command'→'on Nobunaga's orders'Deleted 'legitimate' ― not necessary?
sen.e: Later, on Nobunaga's orders, he became a retainer of Nobunaga's son, Nobutada ODA.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）6月の本能寺の変に際しては、織田信忠と共に二条御所にあったが、信忠の命令で信忠の嫡男・三法師（のちの織田秀信）を引き連れて京都から脱出して美濃岐阜城、そして尾張清洲城に逃れた。
sen.e: He was with Nobutada ODA in Nijyo Gojo during the Honnoji Incident in June 1582 but escaped from Kyoto with Sanposhi (later Hidenobu ODA) to Mino Gifu Castle and then to Owari Kiyosu Castle under Nobutada's order.

He was with Nobutada ODA in the Nijyo Gojo palace during the Honnoji Incident of June 1582 but Nobutada ordered him to escape from Kyoto with Nobutada's son, Sanposhi (later Hidenobu ODA), to Mino Gifu Castle and then to Owari Kiyosu Castle.
sen.cmt: Added 'the' and 'palace''in'→'of'Changed word order.'under Nobutada's order'→'Nobutada ordered him'Added 'Nobutada's son,'―from original Japanese
sen.e: He was with Nobutada ODA in the Nijo-Gosho palace during the Honnoji Incident of June 1582 but Nobutada ordered him to escape from Kyoto with Nobutada's son, Sanposhi (later Hidenobu ODA), to Mino Gifu Castle and then to Owari Kiyosu Castle.

sen.j: 天正11年（1583年）から信長の次男・織田信雄に仕え、信雄から京都所司代に任じられたが、天正12年（1584年）に羽柴秀吉（豊臣秀吉）の勢力が京都に伸張すると、必然的に秀吉の家臣として仕えるようになった。
sen.e: He served under Nobunaga's second son, Nobuo ODA, from 1583 and was appointed to Kyoto shoshidai but when forces of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) expanded to Kyoto, he inevitably began his service under Hideyoshi.

He served Nobunaga's second son, Nobuo ODA, from 1583 and was made Kyoto Shoshidai (or governor) but, as Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI)'s power expanded over Kyoto, he had to work for Hideyoshi.
sen.cmt: Deleted 'under'added definition of Kyoto shoshidai'forces...under'→', as Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI)'s power expanded over Kyoto, he had to work for
sen.e: He served Nobunaga's second son, Nobukatsu ODA, from 1583 and was made Kyoto Shoshidai (or governor) but, as Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI)'s power expanded over Kyoto, he had to work for Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 豊臣政権において京都所司代として朝廷のと交渉役を務め、天正16年（1588年）の後陽成天皇の聚楽第行幸では奉行として活躍している。
sen.e: Under TOYOTOMI Administration, he played the role of the negotiator between the imperial court as the Kyoto Shoshidai and as bugyo in Emperor Goyozei's Jurakudai miyuki (emperor's visit to Jurakudai) in 1588.

As the Kyoto Shoshidai, he played the role of negotiator between the Imperial Court and the Shogunate, and was a Bugyo (commissioner) for the 1588 visit by Emperor Goyozei to the Shogun's Jurakudai palace,.

As the Kyoto Shoshidai, he played the role of negotiator between the Imperial Court and the Shogunate, and was a Bugyo (commissioner) for the 1588 visit by Emperor Goyozei to the Shogun's Jurakudai palace,.

sen.j: その一方で寺社の管理も任され、かつて僧侶だったためにキリシタンを弾圧したりしたが、後に弾圧ばかりではなく融和的な政策も採用している。
sen.e: Meanwhile, he managed temples and shrines, and participated in the suppression of Christian movement as a former monk but later adopted policy that sought conciliation, not just suppression.

He also looked after temples and shrines and, as a former Buddhist monk, participated in the suppression of the Christian movement, though he later adopted a policy of conciliation rather than suppression.
sen.cmt: Meanwhile, he managed'→'He also looked after'Added 'Buddhist''sought conciliation, not just suppression'→'adopted a policy of conciliation rather than suppression'
sen.e: He also looked after temples and shrines and, as a former Buddhist monk, participated in the suppression of the Christian movement, though he later adopted a policy of conciliation rather than suppression.

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）、秀吉の命令で豊臣政権下の五奉行の1人に任じられた。
sen.e: He was ordered to be one of the Go bugyo of TOYOTOMI Administration by Hideyoshi in 1598.
He was made one of the Go-Bugyo of the TOYOTOMI Administration by Hideyoshi in 1598.
He was made one of the Gobugyo of the TOYOTOMI Administration by Hideyoshi in 1598.

sen.j: 秀吉没後は豊臣政権下の内部抗争の沈静化に尽力し、徳川家康は会津征伐を起こそうとしたときも反対している。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi's death, he put an effort to subdue the internal power struggle within TOYOTOMI administration and opposed when Ieyasu TOKUGAWA attempted the conquest of Aizu.
After Hideyoshi's death, he tried to quell the power struggle within the TOYOTOMI administration and was opposed to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's attempted conquest of Aizu.
sen.cmt: put an effort to subdue'→'tried to quell'
sen.e: After Hideyoshi's death, he tried to quell the power struggle within the TOYOTOMI administration and was opposed to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's attempted conquest of Aizu.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）、石田三成が大坂で挙兵すると、玄以は豊臣秀頼の後見人を申し出て大坂に残り、西軍に加担し、家康討伐の弾劾状に署名したにも関わらず、家康に三成の挙兵を知らせたりするなどの内通行為を行なっている。
sen.e: When Mitsunari ISHITADA raised an army in Osaka, Geni declared himself as the guardian of Hideyori TOYOTOMI and remained at Osaka while he secretly informed Ieyasu about Mitsunari's raised army despite the fact that he supported Western Army and signed the impeachment agreement to suppress Ieyasu.

When Mitsunari ISHIDA raised an army in Osaka, Geni declared himself the guardian of Hideyori TOYOTOMI and remained at Osaka while secretly informing Ieyasu about Mitsunari's army, despite the fact that he supported the Western Army and had signed a denunciation of Ieyasu.
sen.cmt: Deleted 'as''the impeachment agreement to suppress'→'a denunciation of'
sen.e: When Mitsunari ISHIDA raised an army in Osaka, Geni declared himself the guardian of Hideyori TOYOTOMI and remained at Osaka while secretly informing Ieyasu about Mitsunari's army, despite the fact that he supported the Western Army and had signed a denunciation of Ieyasu.

sen.j: また、病気を理由にして戦場には出陣しなかった。
sen.e: He also claimed to be ill and did not attend the battle.
He also claimed to be ill and did not take part in the battle.
He also claimed to be ill and did not take part in the battle.

sen.j: これらの行為により、関ヶ原の戦いの後は改易されず、丹波亀山5万石の本領を安堵され、その初代藩主となった。
sen.e: Due to these activities, he was not dismissed from his position after the Battle of Sekigahara and was relieved with 50,000 koku Tamba Kameyama to become its first han leader.
Due to these activities, he was not dismissed from his position after the Battle of Sekigahara and was rewarded with the 50,000 koku Tamba Kameyama, becoming its first han leader.
Due to these activities, he was not dismissed from his position after the Battle of Sekigahara and was rewarded with the 50,000 koku Tamba Kameyama, becoming its first Domain leader.

sen.j: 慶長7年（1602年）5月20日に死去。
sen.e: He passed away on May 20, 1602.
He died on May 20, 1602.
He died on May 20, 1602.

sen.j: 享年63。
sen.e: He died at the age of 63.
He was 63 years old.
sen.cmt: died at the age of 63'→'was 63 years old'
sen.e: He was 63 years old.

sen.j: 長男の秀以は前年に早世していたため、次男の茂勝が後を継いだ。
sen.e: Since the eldest son, Hidemochi died young a year before, Shigekatsu, his second youngest son, inherited the estate.
Since his eldest son, Hidemochi, had died young the year before, Shigekatsu, his second youngest son, inherited the estate.
Since his eldest son, Hidemochi, had died young the year before, Shigekatsu, his second son, inherited the estate.

sen.j: 信長・信忠父子からは思慮深く私欲の無い性格だったことから、信任が厚かったとされている。
sen.e: It is said that he was greatly trusted by Nobunaga and Nobutada (father and son) for he was prudent and lacked personal greediness.
It is said that he was greatly trusted by Nobunaga and Nobutada (father and son) for he was prudent and lacked personal greediness.
It is said that he was greatly trusted by Nobunaga and Nobutada (father and son) for he was prudent and lacked personal greediness.

sen.j: 寺社政策でキリシタンを弾圧したが、後にキリシタンに理解を示し、秀吉がバテレン追放令を出した後の文禄2年（1593年）には隠密裏に京都でキリシタンを保護したりしている。
sen.e: He suppressed Christianity due to Temple and Shrine policy but later showed an understanding of Christianity and secretly sheltered Christians in Kyoto in 1593 after Hideyoshi declared the Bateren (slang for Christianity) expulsion order.

He suppressed Christianity under the Temple and Shrine policy but later showed an understanding of Christianity and secretly sheltered Christians in Kyoto in 1593 after Hideyoshi declared the Bateren (slang for Christianity) expulsion order.

He suppressed Christianity under the Temple and Shrine policy but later showed an understanding of Christianity and secretly sheltered Christians in Kyoto in 1593 after Hideyoshi declared the Bateren (slang for Christianity) expulsion order.

sen.j: また、インド総督ともキリシタン関係で交渉したことがあったとされている。
sen.e: He supposedly negotiated with the government-general of India concerning Christianity.
He supposedly held talks with the governor-general of India concerning Christianity.
He supposedly held talks with the governor-general of India concerning Christianity.

sen.j: ちなみに玄以の2人の息子は、この影響でキリシタンになっている。
sen.e: Geni's two sons became Christians due to these influences.
Geni's two sons became Christians due to these influences.
Geni's two sons became Christians due to these influences.

sen.j: 同じ五奉行の増田長盛が同じく大坂城に留守居役として残り、大坂方（西軍）の情報を提供して家康に内通したにもかかわらず、関ヶ原の戦い後に所領を没収され改易されたのとは対照的である。
sen.e: This was in contrast to Nagamori MASHITA who was also the Go bugyo that stayed in Osaka Castle as rusuiyaku and secretly gave out information of Osaka side (Western army) to Ieyasu, but his estates were confiscated and dismissed from his position after the Battle of Sekigahara.

His fate can be contrasted with Nagamori MASHITA, another Go-Bugyo who remained in Osaka Castle as a rusuiyaku (or caretaker) and secretly gave out information about the Osaka (Western) army to Ieyasu, but who had his estates confiscated and was dismissed from his position after the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.e: His fate can be contrasted with Nagamori MASHITA, another Gobugyo who remained in Osaka Castle as a rusuiyaku (or caretaker) and secretly gave out information about the Osaka (Western) army to Ieyasu, but who had his estates confiscated and was dismissed from his position after the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: 玄以の持つ朝廷とのつながりを利用するため、家康に優遇されたものと思われる。
sen.e: It is believed that Geni was favored by Ieyasu due to his connections with the imperial court.
